results.name: Table of Hamming distances between binary vectors representing i and j, for i >= 0, j >= 0, read by antidiagonals.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 0..200, flattened
example: a(3,5) = 2 because the binary Hamming distance (number of differing bits) between ...0011 and ...0101 is 2.
Triangle formed when the array is read by antidiagonals:
maple: H:= (i, j)-> add(v, v=convert(Bits[Xor](i, j), base, 2)):
seq(seq(H(n, d-n), n=0..d), d=0..20);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Nov 18 2015
mathematica: a[i_, j_] := Total[IntegerDigits[BitXor[i, j], 2]]; Table[a[i-j, j], {i, 0, 20}, {j, 0, i}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 07 2016 *)
program: tabl(nn) = {for(n=0, nn, for(k=0, n, print1(b(bitxor(k, n - k)),", ");); print(););};
print([bin(k^(n - k))[2:].count("1") for k in range(n + 1)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 31 2017
